question: Question_05_(c)
sols:
Here we have several compositions going on. So a first step, would be to
compute the derivative of

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\ln(x^2+2x)\end{align*}

We do this using the chain rule:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
( p(q(x)) )' = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\end{align*}

Here we have that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
p(x) = \ln(x) \qquad q(x) = x^2+2x\end{align*} and

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
p'(x) = \frac{1}{x} \qquad q'(x) = 2x+2\end{align*}

And so:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
( \ln(x^2+2x) )' = \frac{1}{x^2+2x} (2x+2) = \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\end{align*}

And so now, we can use the chain rule again to compute the derivative of

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\ln(\ln(x^2+2x))\end{align*}

Using:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
( p(q(x)) )' = p'(q(x)) \cdot q'(x)\end{align*}

Where

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
p(x) = \ln(x) \qquad q(x) = \ln(x^2+2x)\end{align*} and we have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
p'(x) = \frac{1}{x} \qquad q'(x) = \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\end{align*}

And so we obtain

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
h'(x) = \frac{1}{\ln(x^2+2x)} \cdot \frac{2x+2}{x^2+2x}\end{align*}
hints: Watch out for the multiple use of the chain rule.
